metadata.title: How to Read YouTube Analytics 2025: Data-Driven Growth
metadata.description: Understand YouTube Analytics. Learn which metrics matter for channel growth.

hero.headline: How to Read YouTube Analytics
hero.subheadline: Turn data into growth. Understand what the numbers mean.

sections.content: YouTube gives you incredible data—if you know how to read it. Most creators glance at views and miss the insights that drive growth. Understanding your analytics reveals what's working, what's failing, and exactly what to do next. Here's how to extract actionable insights from your data.

sections.title: Accessing Analytics
content: Click any metric for detailed breakdown

content.title: Watch Time
content.description: Total minutes watched. Primary ranking factor.

content.title: AVD
content.description: Average view duration. Content quality indicator.

content.title: Traffic Sources
content.description: Where views come from. Optimize discovery.

content.title: Audience Retention
content.description: When viewers leave. Fix weak points.

content.title: Demographics
content.description: Who watches. Tailor content to audience.

content.title: Search Terms
content.description: How viewers find you. Content ideas.

sections.title: Analytics Best Practices
content: Compare to your own averages, not others
Retention graph shows exact drop-off points
High CTR + low AVD = clickbait problem
Low CTR + high AVD = packaging problem

faq.question: What's a good CTR?
faq.answer: 4-10% is typical. Higher for established channels, lower for viral/new content reaching broader audiences. Compare to YOUR average, not others. CTR alone doesn't matter—CTR × impressions × AVD is what counts.

faq.question: Why does watch time matter most?
faq.answer: YouTube optimizes for time spent on platform. Watch time directly influences recommendations. A video with 50% retention on 20-minute video beats 80% retention on 3-minute video in total watch time.

faq.question: How to read retention graphs?
faq.answer: Flat line is ideal—viewers watching through. Steep early drop = weak hook. Drops at specific points = content issues there. Spikes often indicate replays of valuable moments.

faq.question: Impressions but low CTR?
faq.answer: YouTube testing your content with broader audience. Thumbnail/title not compelling enough. If CTR drops when impressions rise, that's normal—broader audience is less targeted.
